title: London is Home to the Highest Proportion of Vacant Properties in England
text:
Greater London is home to one in 10 of the unoccupied homes in England, according to a report by HomeProtect.



Of the more than 200,000 properties sitting vacant in England, 22,481 of them are in the capital, the home insurance provider said in the report, released earlier this week.



More: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas Buy and Sell in the New York Suburbs

There are a number of reasons why a home might be vacant, including that they’re pied-à-terres, for sale, in probate or under renovation.



And in London in particular, wealthy buyers are known to keep homes vacant.



“Multi-millionaires will buy properties with no intent of even using them as a home or holiday home, but purely to be held as an investment,” Emily Evans, an estate agent and property developer, said in the report. “Another reason is Airbnb—the government has made it difficult to be a landlord, meaning landlords are now selling up or choosing to adopt the Airbnb holiday home model, over a traditional residential let.”



Within the city, the highest proportion of empty homes are within the London Borough of Southwark, where 8% of properties are vacant, the report said.



The area is home to a lot of part-time homes and Airbnbs, according to Ms. Evans.



From Penta: J.K. Rowling Donates $18.9 Million to MS Research

The London Borough of Croydon, where 7% of homes are empty, followed. As did Camden, Lewisham and Kensington & Chelsea, which each have 5% of their homes sitting vacant, the report said.



Outside of London, Birmingham has the next highest number of vacant properties, though at 4,283, the figure is a distant second place.



“Due to the cost of properties in the main cities like London being so high over the last five years, landlords have been turning to cities like Birmingham and Liverpool,” Ms. Evans said. “They’re not as easy areas for letting in, however, so many of these properties are staying unoccupied for longer. These cities are also popular ‘weekend break’ locations, so the properties could be used as Airbnbs.”
